questions.text: A previously healthy 46-year-old woman comes to her physician because of an itchy rash on her legs. She denies any recent trauma, insect bites, or travel. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the oral cavity shows white lace-like lines on the buccal mucosa. A photograph of the rash is shown. A biopsy specimen of the skin lesion is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Decreased thickness of the stratum granulosum
Deposition of antibodies around epidermal cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased thickness of the stratum granulosum is seen in psoriasis, which can also present with lesions on the extensor surfaces. Unlike the lesions seen here, psoriatic lesions are typically scaly plaques with a silver hue.
Image Description:

Multiple sharply demarcated confluent plaques covered with hard, coarse, silver-white scaling are visible over the extensor surface of the knee.

This is the characteristic appearance of plaque psoriasis.

B) INCORRECT:

Inflammation of subcutaneous fatty tissue (panniculitis) can occur in conditions such as erythema nodosum, lipodermatosclerosis, and Behcet disease. Behcet disease can manifest with nodular skin lesions on the shins (erythema nodosum), genital lesions, and oral lesions. However, the oral lesions are aphthous, circular, painful, and recurrent, in contrast to the lace-like lesions seen in this case.
Image Description:

Poorly demarcated red nodules are seen on the extensor sides of both lower legs with peripheral edema of the lower left leg and foot.

These findings are characteristic of erythema nodosum.

C) INCORRECT:

Proliferation of atypical squamous cell epithelium can be seen in condylomata. Condylomata acuminata are caused by HPV and manifest as tanned, cauliflower-like papules. Condylomata lata are caused by Treponema pallidum and have a distinct flat, wart-like appearance. They tend to grow in moist areas such as the genitalia, unlike the lesions seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Multiple exophytic, cauliflower-like, confluent, erythematous lesions are visible in the perianal region.

D) CORRECT:

Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory disease and may present with cutaneous, oral, and/or genital lesions. Histopathological examination of lichen planus lesions often shows band-like (sawtooth-like) lymphocytic infiltration at the dermal-epidermal junction. Other important histopathologic features include hyperkeratosis, wedge-shaped hypergranulosis, and irregular acanthosis.
Image Description:

Linear, lymphocyte infiltrate at the dermoepidermal junction

E) INCORRECT:

Vascular endothelial proliferations are seen in conditions such as bacillary angiomatosis and Kaposi sarcoma, both of which can present with purple-red papules in the lower extremities. However, patients usually have a history of HIV infection, and white lace-like mucosal lesions would not be expected with either of these conditions.

F) INCORRECT:

Pemphigus vulgaris is associated with anti-desmosomal IgG antibodies, which are deposited in a net-like pattern around epidermal cells. Patients with pemphigus vulgaris present with flaccid intraepidermal bullae, painful oral blisters, and a positive Nikolsky sign. This patient's cutaneous lesions appear intact and flat and there is no blistering, making this diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph (direct immunofluorescence using anti-IgG antibodies)

There is intercellular IgG deposition within the epidermis and acantholysis of the cells near the floor of the blister (resulting in a “row of tombstones” appearance).
questions.hint: The presence of planar, purple, polygonal, pruritic, papules and plaques on the extensor surface (shins) and oral lace-like reticular lesion (Wickham striae) indicate a diagnosis of lichen planus.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man comes to the office because of lesions on his tongue and both inner cheeks that he first noticed 2 weeks ago. He says that he stopped drinking juice and eating spicy food because they lead to a burning sensation on his tongue. He has chronic hepatitis C infection treated with ledipasvir and sofosbuvir. He has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 16 years and drinks three to four glasses of wine per week. His vital signs are within normal limits. Oral examination shows bilateral white lesions on the buccal mucosa that cannot be scraped off; a photograph of a lesion is shown. There are similar lesions and multiple red patches on the tongue. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Maintaining good oral hygiene is an important part of the prophylaxis of various conditions, such as aphthous stomatitis, which is painful and typically manifests with ulcers with a yellow-gray base and erythematous borders. In contrast, this patient has characteristic signs of oral LP (e.g., white, lacelike mucosal lesions). Maintaining good oral hygiene is important for preventing exacerbation of oral LP, but it is not the first-line therapy.
Image Description:

Two shallow ulcers with erythematous and well-defined borders are visible on the buccal mucosa of the lower lip.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical nystatin therapy is used to treat oropharyngeal candidiasis (i.e., oral thrush), which typically manifests with white lesions in the oral cavity. However, unlike this patient's lesions, oral thrush can be easily scraped off and does not cause a burning sensation when exposed to certain foods. Although topical nystatin therapy can be used to manage complications associated with oral LP treatment, it is not used to manage this condition.
Image Description:

There is a distinct area of white plaque on the oral mucosa that can be scraped off.

This finding is characteristic oropharyngeal candidiasis (oral thrush).

C) CORRECT:

Topical corticosteroid therapy is the first-line treatment of symptomatic oral LP. Oral LP typically manifests bilaterally and is classified into three clinical subtypes. The most common subtype is reticular, which is characterized by Wickham striae and is usually asymptomatic. Erythematous oral LP manifests with red patches, pain, irritation, and/or burning sensation, whereas erosive oral LP is characterized by erosions and ulcers. Two or more subtypes of oral LP can occur simultaneously, as seen in this patient. While cutaneous LP usually self-resolves after 1–2 years, oral LP has a chronic course; the main goal of treatment is symptom relief and reduction of erosive lesion. Asymptomatic oral LP does not require treatment, but follow-up is necessary every 6–12 months to assess the risk of malignant transformation.

The most common side effect of oral topical corticosteroid treatment is oropharyngeal candidiasis. Therefore, patients should be closely monitored and given antifungal therapy as needed.

D) INCORRECT:

Cryotherapy is used to treat oral leukoplakia, which manifests with painless white lesions that cannot be scraped off. Tobacco smoking and alcohol consumption are strong risk factors for oral leukoplakia, putting this patient at increased risk. However, the characteristic lesions of this condition are thick patches rather than lacelike lesions, and red patches on the tongue are not typical of oral leukoplakia.
Image Description:

Poorly demarcated, white plaque on the buccal mucosa that cannot be scraped off.

This finding is most consistent with oral leukoplakia, which may develop into squamous cell carcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral acyclovir therapy is used to treat herpetic gingivostomatitis, which manifests with painful erythematous mucosal ulcerations. Although herpetic gingivostomatitis may develop in immunocompetent adolescents or adults, it typically occurs in children (6 months to 5 years of age) or immunocompromised patients and is usually accompanied by oral pain and fever. Oral LP requires a different treatment.
Image Description:

Multiple red erosions can be seen on the lips. Intact vesicles with surrounding erythema are visible on the tongue.

This is the characteristic appearance of herpetic gingivostomatitis.
questions.hint: Bilateral lacelike lesions (Wickham striae) and red patches on the tongue in a patient with hepatitis C indicate oral lichen planus (LP).

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the office because of a 4-week history of an itchy rash on both of his wrists. Upon questioning, he mentions that he has also had difficulty swallowing and a 2-kg (4-lb) weight loss during this time. He says he had the same rash 6 months ago and that it resolved without treatment. He has no history of serious illness. His family history is remarkable for psoriasis in his grandfather. He does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. A photograph of the lesions is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Plaque psoriasis may manifest with symmetrically distributed well-demarcated and pruritic papules and plaques. However, unlike this patient's rash, the lesions are typically erythematous with diffuse silvery-white scaling. Moreover, psoriatic plaques most commonly occur on the extensor surfaces of the elbows, knees, and scalp.
Image Description:

Confluent erythematous plaques with silver-white scaling are visible on the extensor surface of the upper limb.

B) INCORRECT:

Sarcoptes scabiei infection may manifest with pruritic papules, which are most commonly seen on the wrists. However, unlike this patient's rash, the primary lesions are commonly erythematous and also include vesicles and burrows (thin, curvilinear lines in the superficial dermis). In addition, scabies-related pruritus is severe (particularly at night).
Image Description:

Multiple patches of erythematous, scaly papules and burrows are visible on the back of the hand. Some of the lesions are excoriated. There are numerous tiny lesions; more generalized erythema can be seen on the fingers.

This appearance is typical of classic scabies.

C) INCORRECT:

Lichen sclerosus manifests with well-demarcated, pruritic papules and plaques. However, unlike this patient's rash, lichen sclerosus lesions are typically white and may be surrounded by a red inflamed halo. Furthermore, this condition most commonly develops in postmenopausal women and is usually limited to the anogenital region. Extragenital manifestation (e.g., back, shoulders, wrists) is rare.
Image Description:

Upper back of a female patient

Multiple white plaques with a dry, wrinkled appearance are visible.

These findings are suggestive of extragenital lichen sclerosus. However, the diagnosis requires histological confirmation.

D) INCORRECT:

Atopic dermatitis (AD) is an inflammatory skin disease that typically manifests with pruritus and dry skin on the flexor surfaces of the extremities. However, unlike this patient's features, AD usually develops in antecubital or popliteal fossa with lichenified lesions or nummular eczema. In addition, patients with AD are typically first diagnosed in early childhood, and this patient's medical history is unremarkable.
Image Description:

A scaly, erythematous plaque surrounded by multiple, partly confluent, follicular papules is visible on the skin of the antecubital fossa.

This finding is characteristic of atopic dermatitis.

E) CORRECT:

Lichen planus (LP) is a chronic relapsing cutaneous (e.g., skin, scalp), mucosal (e.g., esophagus), and/or genital disorder that is most prevalent in individuals 30–60 years of age. Symptoms vary depending on the subtype of the disease. Skin lesions usually develop in a bilateral, symmetrical pattern on the wrists, lower extremities, and anogenital region. Esophageal LP can lead to difficulty swallowing (i.e., dysphagia). LP is diagnosed clinically based on the presence of typical skin lesions (6 Ps of lichen planus). Additional testing (e.g., punch biopsy) is performed to confirm the diagnosis and rule out conditions that may manifest with similar lesions (e.g., lichen sclerosus, psoriasis) or malignancy (e.g., squamous cell carcinoma). Dermoscopy can be used to visualize Wickham's striae on the surface of mucosal lesions. Because of the association between the two conditions, HCV screening should also be considered.

Lichenoid drug eruption is a dermatological condition that is triggered by certain drugs (e.g., thiazides, beta blockers, ACE inhibitors, quinines) and manifests with diffuse lesions that closely resemble but are not histologically identical to LP.

F) INCORRECT:

Dermatitis herpetiformis may manifest with recurrent bilateral, symmetrical, and pruritic papules. However, unlike this patient's features, the typical manifestation of dermatitis herpetiformis includes tense, grouped, subepidermal vesicles and/or bullae commonly affecting the extensor surfaces of elbows, knees, and buttocks. Furthermore, this patient's dysphagia raises suspicion for mucosal involvement, which is not characteristic of dermatitis herpetiformis.
Image Description:

Grouped, erythematous, papulovesicular lesions that are partially excoriated (presumably due to pruritus) can be seen on the dorsal forearm.

These findings, especially in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with multiple polygonal, planar, pruritic, purple papules and plaques (six Ps) with well-demarcated, irregular borders in the flexor wrists.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman reports a 3-month history of a pruritic eruption on her volar forearms and wrists that has not been alleviated by over-the-counter therapies. She takes no medications, and her medical history is notable only for chronic infection with hepatitis C virus.
Examination reveals multiple 4- to 9-mm, flat-topped, violaceous papules, some of which are in a linear configuration, on the volar forearms and wrists (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cryoglobulinemia is associated with hepatitis C virus infection, but it appears as a vascular injury pattern with vasculitis, vasculopathy, or both and typically features palpable purpura or areas of ischemia and thrombosis in acral sites such as the helices of the ear.

B) CORRECT:

Lichen planus is an inflammatory disorder of unknown etiology that can affect the skin or mucous membranes. The lesions are classically pruritic, polygonal, flat-topped, and purple.

The lesions of lichen planus may develop in a linear configuration following scratching or other forms of trauma (Koebner phenomenon). Some patients have scalp, nail, and mucosal involvement; in fact, approximately half of patients have oral lichen planus. Treatments include topical glucocorticoids, phototherapy, and occasionally systemic agents.

Lichen planus may be associated with hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection. In addition, some cases are associated with drug culprits, most classically angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors.

Key learning point: In the clinical context of hepatitis C virus infection, a likely cause of pruritic polygonal violaceous papules on the wrists is lichen planus.

C) INCORRECT:

Pityriasis rosea often manifests as pink, erythematous, violaceous, or salmon-colored oval macules and patches, often with a fine scale, on the trunk (in linear arrays resembling a Christmas tree pattern) and on the proximal extremities. The eruption typically starts with a “herald patch,” which is the largest lesion. Pityriasis rosea is associated with reactivation of human herpesvirus-6 and -7.

D) INCORRECT:

Psoriasis is associated with the Koebner phenomenon, but psoriatic lesions manifest as well-demarcated erythematous plaques with silvery scales.

E) INCORRECT:

Syphilis is a great mimicker, and cutaneous manifestations are manifold. In this patient, the 3-month history and localized distribution of lesions would be somewhat atypical for secondary syphilis. However, clinicians should always check syphilis serologies if the patient has any relevant history.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with intensely pruritic lesions on her wrists and ankles bilaterally that are interfering with her sleep. She has tried over-the-counter hydrocortisone cream without improvement. Physical examination is as shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Observation and follow-up with primary care

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Delaying treatment is inappropriate given the patient's severe pruritus that is interfering with her sleep.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient presents with classic cutaneous lichen planus features: bilateral violaceous papules with Wickham striae on typical locations (wrists and ankles) and severe pruritus. High-potency topical corticosteroids are first-line treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Biopsy is indicated when the diagnosis is uncertain, but this patient has classic clinical features of lichen planus. Histological confirmation is unnecessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical calcineurin inhibitors are reserved for patients with refractory disease and are not first-line therapy. These agents must be used with caution due to theoretical risk for malignancy.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral corticosteroids are second-line treatment used for refractory disease but are not an appropriate first-line treatment for this patient.
